saberes: A. Communication.
- Commonly used strategies for the planning, execution, control and repair of the comprehension, production and co-production of oral, written and multimodal texts.
- Knowledge, skills and attitudes that allow carrying out mediation activities in everyday situations.

- Communicative functions of common use appropriate to the field and the communicative context: greet and say goodbye, introduce and introduce oneself; describe people, objects, places, phenomena and events; compare people, objects or situations; situate events in time; situate objects, people and places in space; request and exchange information on everyday matters; give and ask for instructions, warnings, advice and orders; offer, accept and reject help, propositions or suggestions; partially express pleasure or interest and emotions; describe situations present and habitual actions; narrate past events (specific, habitual or interrupted); express future events; express intentions, forecasts and plans for the future; express opinion, possibility, capacity, obligation, prohibition and advice; express simple arguments; express conditions, hypotheses and assumptions; express uncertainty and doubt; express certainty, deduction; reformulate, specify, explain and summarize the discourse.
- Discursive genres in the comprehension, production and co-production of short and simple oral and written texts.

- Commonly used linguistic units and meanings associated with such units such as expression of the entity and its properties, quantity and quality, space and spatial relations, time and temporal relations, affirmation, negation, interrogation and the exclamation, usual logical relationships: cause.

- Lexicon of common use and interest for students related to personal identification, interpersonal relationships, places and environments, leisure and free time, health and physical activity, daily life, housing and home, climate and natural environment, ecology and sustainability, information and communication technologies, school system and training.
- Word formation (prefixing and suffixing) as a method of lexical production.
- False friends and vocabulary comprehension problems that can lead to a failed communication situation.
- Self-confidence and initiative. Error as an integral part of the learning process.
- Commonly used sound, stress, rhythmic and intonation patterns, and general communicative meanings and intentions associated with these patterns.
- Commonly used spelling conventions and meanings and communicative intentions associated with formats, patterns and graphic elements.

- Commonly used conversational conventions and strategies, in synchronous or asynchronous format, to initiate, maintain and end communication, take and yield the floor, ask for and give clarifications and explanations, reformulate, compare and contrast, summarize, collaborate, debate, suggest, etc.
- Geographical varieties of the foreign language: differences between them.

- Resources for learning and commonly used strategies for searching and selecting information: dictionaries in any medium, reference books, libraries, digital and computer resources, tools and mobile applications.
- Recognition of intellectual property and copyright on the sources consulted and content used.

- Commonly used analog and digital tools for oral, written, and multimodal comprehension, production, and co-production; and virtual platforms for educational interaction, cooperation, and collaboration (virtual classrooms, videoconferencing, collaborative digital tools, etc.) for learning, communication and the development of projects with speakers or students of the foreign language.
- Graduated readings of literary texts or thematic ones appropriate to the age of the students as a source of linguistic enrichment.
B. Multilingualism.

- Strategies and techniques to respond effectively and with increasing levels of fluency, adaptation and correction to a specific communicative need despite the limitations derived from the level of competence in the foreign language and in the other languages of the own linguistic repertoire.

- Commonly used strategies to identify, organize, retain, recover and creatively use linguistic units (lexicon, morphosyntax, sound patterns, etc.) from the comparison of the languages and varieties that make up the personal linguistic repertoire.
- Commonly used strategies and tools for self-assessment, self-repair, analog and digital, individual and cooperative.
- Expressions and specific vocabulary of common use to exchange ideas about communication, language, learning and communication and learning tools (metalanguage).
- Comparison between languages from elements of the foreign language and other languages: origin and relationships.
C. Interculturality.
- The foreign language as a means of interpersonal and international communication, a source of information and as a tool for social participation and personal enrichment.
- Interest and initiative in carrying out communicative exchanges through different media with speakers or students of the foreign language.

- Commonly used sociocultural and sociolinguistic aspects related to daily life, living conditions and interpersonal relationships; commonly used social conventions; non-verbal language, linguistic courtesy and digital etiquette; culture, norms, attitudes, customs and own values from countries where the foreign language is spoken.
- Specific graded readings for learning the foreign language or based on significant literary works that reflect the idiosyncrasy and culture of the countries and territories where it is spoken.
- Commonly used strategies to understand and appreciate linguistic, cultural and artistic diversity, taking into account ecosocial and democratic values.
- Commonly used strategies for detection and action against discriminatory uses of verbal and non-verbal language.
Syntactic-discursive structures
1. Greet and say goodbye, introduce and introduce yourself.
More formal formulas: How do you do?, Pleased to meet you, etc.
2. Describing people, objects, places, phenomena and events.
Be and have (got).
Present simple vs present continuous
Demonstratives. Personal pronouns.
Possessive determiners and pronouns .
Prepositions and adverbs of place, position, distance, movement and direction.
3. Compare people, objects or situations.
Positive degree adjectives and adjectives ending in –ing and –ed. Comparatives and superlatives (of equality, inferiority and superiority). Expression of quantity: too much/many, not enough.
Some/any and their compounds.
4. Situate events in time.
There is/there are.
Simple past.
Present perfect.
Prepositions: for, since, just. Adverbs: already, still, yet, ever.
5. Locate objects, people and places in space.
There is/there are.
Prepositions: on, under, between, etc. Adverbs of place: there, here, etc.
6. Ask for and exchange information about everyday issues. Questions such as How far, How long, How tall, etc.
Frequency adverbs: always, never, sometimes, etc.
7. Give and ask for instructions, warnings, advice and orders. Imperatives.
Modal verbs: should/ought to, must/have to; be aware of, be careful.

8. Offer, accept and reject help, propositions or suggestions. Modal verbs such as can, could, will, should/ought to, need/have to. Expressions such as Can I help you?, would you like…?, How/what about...? Let's... Why don't we...?
9. Partially express pleasure or interest and emotions. Expressions like Me too.
Expressions like How/ What about + -ing.
Formulas Can/Could I help you? Would you like? Would you feel like?
10. Describe present situations and habitual actions.
Present simple vs present continuous.
11. Narrate past events (specific, regular or interrupted)
Past simple vs past continuous. Used to + infinitive.
Be/get used to + -ing.
12. Express future events.
Future simple.
13. Express intentions, forecasts and plans in the future.
Future simple, be going to, present continuous with future meaning.
14. Express the opinion, the possibility, the capacity, the obligation, the prohibition and the advice.
Expressions like I think, in my opinion, etc.
Modals like may/might, can/could, must/have to, mustn’t, can’t, should/ought to.
Expressions like be able to.
15. Express simple arguments.
Connectors like because, but, and, on the one hand, on the other hand, however, etc.
16. Express conditions, hypotheses and suppositions. Conditions I and II.
Adverbs of possibility: perhaps, maybe. Expressions like I suppose, I guess.
17. Express uncertainty and doubt.
Expressions like I'm not sure, I don't think so, I'm afraid.
Adverbs like unfortunately, unluckily.
18. Express certainty, deduction. Expressions like: I'm sure, I think so. Manners: can, must, can't, will.
Adverbs like definitely, obviously, clearly, etc.
19. Rephrase, specify, explain and summarize the discourse. Expressions like for example, I mean, in short, in conclusion, etc.
criteriosEvaluacion: 1.1 Extract and analyze the overall meaning and main ideas, and select pertinent information from oral, written and multimodal texts on everyday topics, of personal relevance or of public interest close to the student's experience expressed clearly and in the standard language through various supports. (CCL2, CCL4, CD1)

1.2 Interpret and assess the content and discursive features of a wide variety of texts from the fields of interpersonal relationships, the media and learning, as well as literary texts appropriate to the level of maturity of the students. (CCL2, CCL3, CCL4, CP1, CD1, CCEC2)

1.3 Select, organize and apply the most appropriate strategies and knowledge in each communicative situation to understand the general meaning, the essential information and the most relevant details of the texts; infer meanings and interpret non-verbal elements; and search, select and manage information truthful (PC1, PC2, STEM1, CD1, CPSAA5)

2.1 Orally express simple, structured, understandable, coherent and appropriate texts to the communicative situation on everyday matters, of personal relevance or of public interest close to the student's experience, in order to describe, narrate, argue and inform, in different supports, using verbal and non-verbal resources, as well as planning, control, compensation and cooperation strategies (CCL1, CP1, CP2, STEM1, CD3, CPSAA1, CE3, CCEC3)

2.2 Write and disseminate texts of medium length with acceptable clarity, coherence, cohesion, correctness and adaptation to the proposed communicative situation, to the textual typology and to the analogical and digital tools used on daily matters, of personal relevance or of public interest close to his experience, respecting intellectual property and avoiding plagiarism. (CCL1, CP1, CP2, STEM1, CD2, CD3, CPSAA5, CE3, CCEC3)

2.3 Select, organize and apply knowledge and strategies to plan, produce, review and cooperate in the elaboration of coherent, cohesive and appropriate texts to the communicative intentions, the contextual characteristics, the sociocultural aspects and the textual typology, using the physical resources or most appropriate digital media based on the task and the needs of the audience or potential reader to whom the text is addressed. (CCL1, CCL5, CP1, CP2, STEM1, CD2, CD3, CPSAA5, CE1, CE3, CCEC3)

2.4 Describe facts and express concepts, thoughts, opinions or feelings clearly orally or in writing in analog and digital contexts; exchanging appropriate information for different daily contexts of their personal, social, global and educational environment. (CCL1, CP1, CD2, CPSAA1, CE1, CE3, CCEC3)

3.1 Plan, participate and actively collaborate, through various supports, in interactive situations on everyday topics, of personal relevance or of public interest close to the student's experience, showing initiative, empathy and respect for linguistic courtesy and digital etiquette , as well as the different needs, ideas, concerns, initiatives and motivations of the interlocutors (CCL1, CCL5, CP1, CP2, STEM1, CPSAA3, CC3)

3.2 Select, organize and use appropriate strategies to initiate, maintain and end communication, take and give the floor, request and formulate clarifications and explanations, reformulate, compare and contrast, summarize, collaborate, solve problems. (CCL1, CCL5, CP1 , PC2, STEM1, CD2, CPSAA3, CC3)

3.3 Make yourself understood in simple interventions, even if it is necessary to resort to pauses or repetitions, correcting what you want to express showing a cooperative and respectful attitude. (CCL1, CCL5, CP1, CP2, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CC3)

3.4 Carry out projects in a guided way using digital tools or virtual platforms working collaboratively in safe digital environments with an open, respectful and responsible attitude. (CCL1, CCL5, CP2, CD2, CC3)

4.1 Infer and explain texts, concepts and brief and simple communications in situations in which to attend to diversity, showing respect and empathy for the interlocutors and for the languages used, and participating in the solution of problems of intercomprehension and understanding in their environment, relying on various resources and supports (CCL1, CCL5, CP2, CP3, STEM1, CD3, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CC4, CE3, CCEC1)

4.2 Apply strategies that help create bridges, facilitate communication and serve to explain and simplify texts, concepts and messages, and that are appropriate to communicative intentions, contextual characteristics and textual typology, using resources and physical or digital supports in function of the needs of each moment. (CCL1, CCL5, CP1, CP2, STEM1, CD3, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CC4, CE3)
4.3 Use the foreign language as an instrument to deal with situations and solve environmental problems effectively. (CCL1, CCL5, CP1, CP2, CD3, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CC4)

4.4 Use mediation strategies such as interpretation, explanation and summary of the essential, making the most of and organizing the mediator's previous resources and relying on all those who can help. (CCL5, CP1, CP2, CP3, CD3, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CCEC1)
5.1 Compare and discuss the similarities and differences between different languages, reflecting in a progressively autonomous way on their functioning. (CCL3, CPSAA5, CC2)

5.2 Creatively use strategies and knowledge to improve the ability to communicate and learn the foreign language with the support of other participants and analog and digital media. (CCL1, CP2, STEM1, CD2, CD3, CPSAA1, CPSAA5) 5.3 Register and analyze the progress and difficulties in learning the foreign language, selecting the most effective strategies to overcome these difficulties and consolidate learning, carrying out activities for planning one's own learning and self-assessment, such as those proposed in the European Language Portfolio (PEL). or in a learning journal. (CPSAA1, CPSAA4, CPSAA5, CC2)

6.1 Act appropriately, empathetically and respectfully in intercultural situations, building links between different languages and cultures, rejecting any type of discrimination, prejudice and stereotype in everyday communication contexts and proposing solutions to those sociocultural factors that make communication difficult. ( CCL4, CCL5, CP2, CP3, CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CC2, CC3, CCEC1, CCEC2)

6.2 Adapt to the linguistic, literary, cultural and artistic diversity typical of countries where the foreign language is spoken, favoring the development of a shared culture and a citizenry committed to sustainability and democratic values. (CCL4, CCL5, CP2, CP3 , CPSAA1, CPSAA3, CC2, CC3, CCEC1, CCEC2)

6.3 Apply strategies to defend and appreciate linguistic, literary, cultural and artistic diversity, attending to ecological and democratic values and respecting the principles of justice, equity and equality. (CCL4, CCL5, CP2, CP3, CPSAA3, CC2, CC3, CCEC1 ,CCEC2)
